kubejs.ponder.Cobblestone_Generator.head: I want more cobble!
kubejs.ponder.Cobblestone_Generator.text: Upon gathering some materials, you might want to think of making a Cobblestone Generator.
A Cobblestone Generator works by infinitely flowing lava into contacting water, generating cobblestone as a result.
If you break the cobbblestone block...
It's important to limit the water flow so it doesn't reach the lava source.
If you're not careful, your lava will become Obsidian, thus ruining your Cobblestone Generator.
The process is very simple, but it can become very monotonous to break cobblestone by hand...
You might want to find a more §ccreative§r solution to this problem...
kubejs.ponder.apothecary.text_1: This is a Petal Apothecary, it is heavily used in Botania for creating flowers
kubejs.ponder.apothecary.text_2: As an example let's make a pure daisy
kubejs.ponder.apothecary.text_3: With all the resources added we then need to add our catalyst to combine them
kubejs.ponder.basalt_generator.text_1: Another neat function of vanilla minecraft is the Basalt Generator!
kubejs.ponder.basalt_generator.text_2: This generator works under some special conditions:
kubejs.ponder.basalt_generator.text_3: Condition 1: Soul Soil must be present beneath lava.
kubejs.ponder.basalt_generator.text_4: Condition 2: Blue Ice must be adjacent to lava.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_manipulation.text_1: The cocoon reacts to certain items, either dropped on it, or interacted with.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_manipulation.text_2: Using chorus fruits increases the chance to get a Shulker! §cUseful...
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_manipulation.text_3: While using a Gaia Spirit will guarantee a rare spawn. Not sure why you would do this...
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_manipulation.text_4: The Lexica Botania mentions the cocoon reacting to emeralds, but it doesn't seem to be the case.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_1: To use the Cocoon of Caprice, it must be placed on the ground.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_3: A mob will spawn from it! This mob will be a baby if possible.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_4: Most of the time, you will get a common farm animal.
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_5: But there's a small chance to instead pick from an assortment of rarer animals!
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_6: If the cocoon is placed in water or next to water...
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_7: An acquatic mob will appear instead!
kubejs.ponder.cocoon_of_caprice.text_8: Acquatic cocoons have their own set of rarer mobs to spawn.
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_1: This is an Endoflame, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_2: Dropping fuel such as coal near the Endoflame will cause it to be consumed by the flower and generate mana
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_3:
The flower will consume most furnace fuel in a 7x7 square, centered on itself
(Consumption sped up for demonstration)
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_4: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_5: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.endoflame.text_6: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.endoflame_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_1: This is an Entropinnyum, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_2: It generates sizeable chunks of mana by absorbing TNT explosions
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_3: TNT generated from a duplicator machine will function, but yield far less mana.
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_4: It will §cNOT§r absorb the explosion if its mana buffer is not empty!
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_5: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_6: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum.text_7: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.entropinnyum_decay.text_7: I sure hope you got something to shut off the flow of primed tnt when that happens.
kubejs.ponder.fel_pumpkin.text_1: The Fel Pumpkin can help you get a reliable supply of blaze powder even without a fortress available.
kubejs.ponder.fel_pumpkin.text_2: To use it, place it on top of two iron bars, in the same way you would build a snowman.
kubejs.ponder.fel_pumpkin.text_3: A blaze will spawn. But it is not an ordinary blaze.
kubejs.ponder.fel_pumpkin.text_4: It won't drop blaze rods, but a handful of blaze powder.
kubejs.ponder.fel_pumpkin.text_5: Blazes from fel pumpkins can be used for blaze burners as usual.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_1: This is a Gourmaryllis, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_2: It generates mana by consuming food items dropped within a block of it.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_3:
The more nutritious a food is, the longer it takes to digest.
However, the generated mana scales up exponentially.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_4:
Only a single item at a time can be digested.
Any more food in the meantime
§cwill be wasted.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_5: Variety is key. The more varied the foods are, the more mana it will produce, capping out at 8 different foods.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_6: However, using the same food multiple times in a row slows digestion and gives severely diminishing returns.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_7: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_8: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis.text_9: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.gourmaryllis_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_1: This is a Hydroangeas, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_2: It generates small amounts of mana by absorbing source water blocks around it.
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_3: Rainy weather can speed up the production rate, but it is still meager.
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_4: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_5: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas.text_6: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.hydroangeas_decay.text_7: Note: The normal 3-day decay timer of the hydroangeas is disabled here.
kubejs.ponder.ie_hammah.text_1: The Engineer's Hammer is one of the most important tools when working with Immersive Engineering,
kubejs.ponder.ie_hammah.text_2: The hammer can be used to rotate many blocks.
kubejs.ponder.ie_hammah.text_3: The hammer can be also used to configure certain blocks.
kubejs.ponder.ie_hammah.text_4: For example, right-clicking a side of an accumulator, will set whether it's an input, an output, or neither.
kubejs.ponder.ie_hammah.text_5: Tip: Shift-Right clicking will set the opposite side, if available!
kubejs.ponder.ie_multiblock_assembly.tex: The hammer is needed to assemble Immersive Engineering's multiblocks.
First, build the multiblock. Follow the instructions in the Engineer's manual, or use the Multiblock Projector.
Once the multiblock is built, right click the correct block with the hammer.
The correct block is highlighted in the manual.
If the multiblock is built incorrectly, nothing happens instead.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_1: This is a Munchdew, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_2:
It generates mana by devouring any leaves in a
17x16x17 cube at a rate of 5 blocks per second.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_3: Once it misses a chance to eat, it will stop and enter a 80s cooldown.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_4: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_5: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.munchdew.text_6: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.munchdew_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.munchdew_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.munchdew_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_1: This is a Narslimmus, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_2: It generates mana by absorbing any slime mobs that wander within 2 blocks of the flower
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_3: Larger slimes will produce more mana.
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_4: The slime must be naturally spawned. Use the slime in a bottle to find a suitable location.
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_5: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_6: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus.text_7: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.narslimmus_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.pure_daisy.text_1: This is a Pure Daisy it is a Functional Flower that changes blocks or fluids placed around it
kubejs.ponder.pure_daisy.text_2: Now we wait for a short period of time and the smooth stone should be changed into livingrock
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_1: This is a Respawn Anchor. It allows you to set your respawn point.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_2: To use it, simply right click it with a block of glowstone.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_3: In total, it'll hold 4 charges, meaning 4 glowstone blocks.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_4: Upon respawn, the Respawn anchor will lose one charge.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_5: You can see how many charges remain in this here circle.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_6: You can add glowstone autonomously via a dispenser facing the Respawn Anchor.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_7: And you may either use a comparator to calculate how many uses the Anchor has...
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_8: ...or you may use an observer to emit a pulse whenever you respawn.
kubejs.ponder.respawn_anchor.text_9: Oh, and don't worry about beds. §cTrust me.§r
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_1: This is a Rosa Arcana, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_2: It generates mana from experience. It will drain XP from players standing next to it.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_3: It will also absorb any experience orb within one block of itself.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_4: Enchanted items dropped near it will have the enchantments stripped from them and turned into xp orbs, like with a grindstone. Does not affect curses.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_5: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_6: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana.text_7: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
kubejs.ponder.rosa_arcana_decay.text_7: If the enchanter block appears outside of a valid structure, you have one tick of time...
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_1: Although more intricate, you may also want to build a Stone Generator.
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_10:
Oh, and stone can be mined faster than cobblestone.
§cDo keep this in mind.§r
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_2: While a Cobblestone Generator works by flowing lava next to water...
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_3: A Stone Generator works by flowing lava ON TOP of water.
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_4: Something else to note is that, once placed, lava doesn't flow upon neccesity. It ALWAYS tries to flow whenever possible.
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_5: This is known as the "Global Timer".
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_6: "Why is this important?" you may ask.
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_7: If you break the stone block at the wrong time...
kubejs.ponder.stone_generator.text_9: ...resulting in the creation of cobblestone instead.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_1: This is a Thermalily, one of the many mana generating flowers
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_10: The comparator signal does NOT tick down. It is up to the player to figure out how to use this value to delay the next lava block.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_11: The thermalily can only absorb one block of lava at a time.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_12: If you try to place more lava while it's generating or on cooldown...
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_13: To use a mana generating flower, it must be connected to a mana spreader
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_14: Either place the flower near an existing spreader...
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_15: ...or link it manually with a Wand of the Forest
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_2: It generates a lot of mana by absorbing nearby lava source blocks.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_3: After absorbing lava, it will generate mana for about 45 seconds.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_4: When it stops generating mana, it will enter a cooldown period.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_5: The cooldown can vary from 20 seconds to 5 whole minutes
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_6: The cooldown can be read with a comparator.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_7: The comparator output is off only while generating mana
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_8: When the cooldown starts, the comparator outputs a signal based on the length
kubejs.ponder.thermalily.text_9: The signal strength grows by 1 for every 20 seconds of cooldown
kubejs.ponder.thermalily_decay.text_1:
§cEntropy comes for all. 
§rThese flowers cannot handle the stress of generating mana forever.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily_decay.text_2: After enough time has passed and enough mana has been generated...
kubejs.ponder.thermalily_decay.text_4: It will crumble into a pile of mush and some other items.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily_decay.text_5: A block can also get left behind where the flower once stood.
kubejs.ponder.thermalily_decay.text_6:
You will need the mush for progression.
Better automate flower production!
